Scheme 1 Structures of vanadium(III) complexes considered in this work. Scheme 1 Scheme 2 Proposed structures of intermediates 2, 3, 4. Scheme 2 Fig. 1 Ethylene polymerization rate vs. time for the 1/MAO catalyst system (entry 1 from Table 1). The resulting PE has ultrahigh molecular weight, the viscosity average molecular weight was found to be about 6·106 g/mol (Table 1, entry 1). The addition of external THF (which is also present in the structure of the pre-catalyst 1) hampered the polymerization activity (Table 1, entry 2). The use of AlMe3/[Ph3C][B(C6F5)4] as activator led to a lower activity (entry 3). Fig. 1 Fig. 2 1H NMR spectrum of 1 (CH2Cl2, 25 °C, [V]=0.01M) in the 120…20ppm range (a), and in the 20…−1ppm range (b). 2H NMR spectrum of 1a (CH2Cl2, 25 °C, [V]=0.01M) (c). 2H NMR spectrum of 1b (CH2Cl2, 25 °C, [V]=0.01M) (d). Resonance assignment is given in Scheme 1. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 1H NMR spectrum ([Al]/[B]/[V]=10:1.2:1, [V]=0.01M, toluene-d 8/DFB (3/1), −40 °C) of the sample 1/AlMe3/[Ph3C][B(C6F5)4] in the range 120…8ppm (a) and 8…−2ppm (b). 2H NMR spectrum ([Al]/[B]/[V]=10:1.2:1, toluene/DFB (3/1), −40 °C) of the sample 1a/AlMe3/[Ph3C][B(C6F5)4] (c). 2H NMR spectrum ([Al]/[B]/[V]=10:1.2:1, toluene/DFB (3:1), −40 °C) of the sample 1b/AlMe3/[Ph3C][B(C6F5)4] (d). 2H NMR spectrum ([Al]/[B]/[V]=10:1.2:1, toluene/DFB (3/1), −40 °C) of the sample 1/AlMe3/[Ph3C][B(C6F5)4]/THF-d 8, [THF]/[V]=5:1 (e). Asterisks mark resonances of the isotopic impurities in the toluene. Resonance assignment is given in Scheme 1. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 1H NMR spectrum (toluene-d8/DFB, −40 °C) of the sample 1/MAO ([Al]/[V]=40:1, [V]=0.01M) in the range 150…8ppm (a) and in the range 8…−2ppm (b). Asterisks mark impurities of grease. Double asterisks mark impurities in MAO. Resonance assignment is given in Scheme 1. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 1H NMR spectrum of the sample 1/MAO/THF (toluene-d 8/DFB, −40 °C, [Al]/[V]/[THF]=40:1:10, [V]=0.01M) in the range 160…5ppm (a) and in the range 5…−2ppm (b). 2H NMR spectrum of the sample 1a/MAO/THF (toluene/DFB, −40 °C, [Al]/[V]/[THF]=40:1:10, [V]=0.01M) (c). 2H NMR spectrum of the sample 1b/MAO/THF (toluene/DFB, −40 °C, [Al]/[V]/[THF]=40:1:10, [V]=0.01M) (d). 2H NMR spectrum of the sample 1/MAO/THF-d8 (toluene/DFB, −40 °C, [Al]/[V]/[THF-d8]=40:1:10, [V]=0.01M) (e). Asterisks mark resonances of the isotopic impurities in the toluene and 1.2-difluorobenzene. Resonance assignment is given in Scheme 1. Fig. 5 Table 1 Ethylene polymerization catalyzed by 1 a . A set of the nearly located resonances corresponds to the CHnD3-n (n=0, 1, 2) groups in the ketimine moiety. b Sample 1b/AlMe3/[Ph3C][B(C6F5)4] (toluene/DFB, [Al]/[B]/[V]=10:1.2:1, [V]=0.01M). c Sample 1/AlMe3/[Ph3C][B(C6F5)4]/THF-d8 (toluene/DFB, [Al]/[B]/[V]/[THF-d 8]=10:1.2:1:10, [V]=0.01M). d Sample 1a/MAO/THF (toluene/DFB, −40 °C, [Al]/[V]/[THF]=40:1:10, [V]=0.01M). A set of the nearly located resonances corresponds to the CHnD3-n (n=0, 1, 2) groups in the ketimine moiety. e Sample 1b/MAO/THF (toluene/DFB, −40 °C, [Al]/[V]/[THF]=40:1:10, [V]=0.01M). f Sample 1/MAO/THF-d8 (toluene/DFB, −40 °C, [Al]/[V]/[THF-d8]=40:1:10, [V]=0.01M). 1H and 2H NMR spectroscopic study of the ion pairs formed upon the activation of vanadium(III) α-diimine pre-catalyst with AlMe3/[Ph3C][B(C6F5)4] and MAO Igor E. Soshnikov a b Nina V. Semikolenova a Konstantin P. Bryliakov a b Vladimir A. Zakharov a b Evgenii P. Talsi a b ⁎ a Boreskov Institute of Catalysis, Siberian Branch of the Russian Academy of Sciences, 630090, Novosibirsk, Russian Federation Boreskov Institute of Catalysis Siberian Branch of the Russian Academy of Sciences Novosibirsk 630090 Russian Federation b Novosibirsk State University, 630090, Novosibirsk, Russian Federation Novosibirsk State University Novosibirsk 630090 Russian Federation ⁎ Corresponding author at: Boreskov Institute of Catalysis, Siberian Branch of the Russian Academy of Sciences Novosibirsk, 630090, Russain Federation. Boreskov Institute of Catalysis Siberian Branch of the Russian Academy of Sciences Novosibirsk 630090 Russian Federation Graphical abstract 1H and 2H NMR spectroscopic characterization of the V(III) ion-pair intermediates formed upon the activation of α-diimine vanadium(III) chloride L3,5−MeVIIICl3(THF) (L3,5−Me =1,4-bis-3,5-dimethylphenyl-2,3-dimethyl-1,4-diazabuta-1,3-diene) with AlMe3/[Ph3C][B(C6F5)]4 and MAO is reported. In contrast to previously reported heterobinuclear ion pairs of the type [L1(R)VIII(μ-R)2AlMe2]+[A]− (L1 =bis(imino)pyridine ligand, [A]− =[B(C6F5)4]− or [MeMAO]−, R=Me or Cl), species of the type [L3,5−MeVMe2(THF)2]+[B(C6F5)4]−, [L3,5−MeVMe2(THF)2]+[MeMAO]− and [L3,5−MeVMe2 +⟵MeMAO−] were identified. Keywords Homogeneous ethylene polymerization Post-metallocene α-diimine vanadium(III) chloride NMR of the paramagnetic molecules Ion pairs 1 Introduction In the last 10–15 years, post-metallocene vanadium complexes have been extensively studied as pre-catalysts of ethylene homo- and co-polymerization [1–27]. At the same time, the nature of the active species of polymerization has in fact remained a “black box” since there were no direct data on the structure of such species [1a,b,3,28–32]. In effect, their nature continues to be debated controversially; trivalent, tetravalent, and pentavalent alkyl vanadium complexes have been previously considered as potential active species of polymerization [1,3,28–32]. The major technical drawbacks hampering the isolation of the vanadium intermediates or their spectroscopic detection and characterization are their low stability [1][1a] as well as their paramagnetism, resulting in broad and paramagnetically shifted NMR resonances [3,29–31]. Recently, we have reported the first 1H and 2H NMR spectroscopic characterization of vanadium species formed upon the activation of a V(III) bis(imino)pyridine pre-catalyst with AlMe3/[Ph3C][B(C6F5)]4 and MAO [32]. It has been shown that the activation of the bis(imino)pyridine vanadium(III) chloride L1VIIICl3 {L1 =[2,6-(ArNCMe)2C5H3N], Ar=2,6- i Pr2C6H3; 2,6-Me2C6H3; 2,4,6-Me3C6H2; 3,5-F2C6H3} with AlMe3/[Ph3C][B(C6F5)]4 or MAO leads to the formation of heterobinuclear ion pairs of the type [L1(R)VIII(μ-R)2AlMe2]+[A]− ([A] − = [B(C6F5)]4 − or [MeMAO]−, R=Me or Cl). Besides bis(imino)pyridine ligands, α-diimine ligands were also successfully used for the design of post-metallocene ethylene polymerization catalysts [3,33]. Herein, we report the 1H and 2H NMR spectroscopic characterization of V(III) species formed upon activation of α-diimine vanadium(III) pre-catalyst L3,5−MeVIIICl3(THF) (L3,5−Me =1,4-bis-3,5-dimethylphenyl-2,3-dimethyl-1,4-diazabuta-1,3-diene) (complex 1, Scheme 1 ) with AlMe3/[Ph3C][B(C6F5)]4 and MAO. Unexpectedly, ion pairs of the type [L3,5−MeVMe2(THF)2]+[B(C6F5)4]−, [L3,5−MeVMe2(THF)2]+[MeMAO]− and [L3,5−MeVMe2 +⟵MeMAO−] were observed in the systems 1/AlMe3/[Ph3C][B(C6F5)]4, 1/MAO/THF, and 1/MAO, correspondingly. 2 Experimental All manipulations with air- and moisture-sensitive materials were performed in an argon-filled glove-box. All solvents used were dried with 4 Å molecular sieves and distilled under dry argon. Complexes 1, 1a, 1b were synthesized via simple reaction of the corresponding α-diimine ligands with VCl3 in THF media [3]. 2H-enriched 3,5-dimethylaniline and 2,3-butanedione were prepared according to Ref. [34]. Organoaluminum co-catalysts (AlMe3, MAO) and [Ph3C][B(C6F5)4] were purchased from Aldrich. Al(CD3)3 was synthesized by Dr. D. Babushkin according to the published procedure [35]. Solid MAO samples for the NMR experiments were obtained via vacuum distillation of TMA from the commercial MAO solution at room temperature [36]. Ethylene polymerization was performed in a 0.3L steel reactor. A solution of the pre-catalyst (∼2μmoL) in 1mL of toluene/CH2Cl2 (9/1) was introduced into the reactor in a sealed glass ampoule. The reactor was evacuated at 80°C, cooled down to 20°C and then charged with the freshly prepared solution (50cm3) of the co-catalyst in toluene. After setting up the desired temperature (50°C) and ethylene pressure (5bar), the reaction was started by breaking the ampoule with the pre-catalyst. During the polymerization, ethylene pressure, temperature and stirring speed were maintained constant. The experimental unit was equipped with an automatic computer-controlled system for the ethylene feed, maintaining the required pressure, recording the ethylene consumption and providing the kinetic curve output both in the form of a table and as a graph. Viscosity (η) of the polymers was measured in decalin at 135°C on an Ubbelohde viscosimeter. The viscosity-average molecular weight Mv was calculated according to the Mark–Houwink equation: Mv =(η/K)1/α, where the Mark–Hauwink coefficients K=67.7×10−5; α=0.67, according to Ref. [37]. The samples for NMR spectroscopy were prepared in the glovebox under an argon atmosphere. 1H and 2H NMR spectra were measured on a Bruker Avance 400MHz NMR spectrometer at 400.130 and 61.422MHz, respectively, using 5mm o.d. glass NMR tubes. 1H chemical shifts were referenced to the residual peak of CD2 HC6D5 (δ 2.09); 2H chemical shifts were referenced to the CH2 DC6H5 impurities (δ 2.1) in toluene. For the pre-saturation of the DFB or CH2Cl2 resonances, zgpr pulse program was used. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Ethylene polymerization data Upon the activation with MAO, complex 1 displays moderate average activity in ethylene polymerization (Table 1 ). The time profile of ethylene consumption rate (Fig. 1 ) shows high initial polymerization rate followed by rapid decay within ca. 2min, but further the rate of polymerization was almost constant. 3.2 1H and 2H NMR spectra of V(III) pre-catalysts Complex 1 is paramagnetic due to the high-spin (S =1) d2 configuration of vanadium(III). Its 1H NMR spectrum (CH2Cl2, 25°C, [V]=0.01M) displays broad paramagnetically shifted resonances ranging from δ 110 to 0 (Fig. 2 a, b). For the assignment of 1H resonances of 1, selectively deuterated complexes 1a and 1b have been prepared (1a contains deuterated ketimino groups (40% 2H), and 1b contains deuterated orto- and para-aromatic protons (80% 2H), Scheme 1). In 2002, Grassi and co-workers reported the 1H NMR spectrum of complex 1x (Scheme 1) with the structure similar to 1 [5]. The authors discovered that the non-symmetrical environment of the vanadium center in 1x leads to the magnetic non-equivalency of the symmetrically located ligand protons. The same nonequivalence has been found for complex 1. The resonances A and A′ in the 1H NMR spectrum of 1 belong to the two non-equivalent ketimine groups (Fig. 2a). The 2H NMR spectrum of 1a displays two signals at δ 100 and 101.5, denoted as Ad , and one signal at δ 31 denoted as Ad′ (Fig. 2c, Table 2 ). Two signals at δ 100 and 101.5 belong to the NCCD 3, and NCCD 2H groups of 1a. In contrast to Ad , a single resonance Ad′ at δ 31 has been observed (Fig. 2c), due to a smaller difference between the chemical shifts of the corresponding NCCD 3, and NCCD 2H 2H NMR signals. The resonances C and C′ (Fig. 2b) on the basis of their integral values were assigned to CH 3-substituents in the aromatic rings. Peaks D and F (Fig. 2a,b) belong to a THF molecule coordinated to the vanadium center. The addition of THF-d 8 (10 equiv) to the solution of complex 1 in CH2Cl2, leads to the disappearance of resonances D and F in the 1H NMR spectrum, and the appearance of the corresponding peaks Dd and Fd in the 2H NMR spectrum of 1/THF-d 8. It is logical to expect that the broader and more paramagnetically shifted resonance D corresponds to the α-THF protons (located closer to the paramagnetic center), while the β-THF protons give rise to the narrower resonance F (Table 2) [5]. The resonances B, B′ and E, E′ belong to the ortho- and para-protons of the aromatic rings of 1 (Fig. 2b, Table 2). The 2H NMR spectrum of 1b displays resonances Bd , Bd′ and Ed , Ed′ (Fig. 2d). The resonances B′ and E partially overlap in the 1H and 2H NMR spectra. 3.3 Reaction of 1 with AlMe3/[Ph3C][B(C6F5)4] Combining 1 with AlMe3/[Ph3C][B(C6F5)4] in toluene-d 8 at −40 °C leads to an immediate precipitation of an oily phase in the bottom of the NMR-tube. The addition of 1,2-difluorobenzene (DFB) to the sample (∼25 vol.%) significantly improves the solubility of the reaction products and a transparent homogeneous solution is formed. The 1H NMR spectrum of the sample 1/AlMe3/[Ph3C][B(C6F5)4] ([Al]/[B]/[V]=10:1.2:1, [V]=0.01M) in toluene-d 8/DFB at −40 °C displays broad paramagnetically shifted resonances of a new high-spin (S =1) vanadium(III) complex 2 (Fig. 3 , Table 3 ). The latter is more symmetrical than 1; as distinct from 1, the two ketimine CH3-groups of 2 are magnetically equivalent (single resonance A is observed, Fig. 3a). Four other CH3-groups of 2 are also equivalent (single resonance C is observed, Fig. 3b). The 2H NMR spectrum of 2 formed in the system 1a/AlMe3/[Ph3C][B(C6F5)4] in toluene exhibits one set of resonances Ad from the NCCD xH3-x (x=1-3) groups of 2 (Fig. 3c, Table 3). The 2H NMR spectrum of 2 formed in the system 1b/AlMe3/[Ph3C][B(C6F5)4] displays single resonances from the aromatic orto- and para-protons (Bd and Ed , Fig. 3d). The addition of THF-d 8 to the sample 1/AlMe3/[Ph3C][B(C6F5)4] allows the observation of 2H resonances of THF-d 8 molecules coordinated to the vanadium center of 2 (signals Dd and Fd , Fig. 3e). The peak Dd is broader than Fd (Table 3), reflecting a closer location of the deuterons Dd to the perturbing vanadium center. Therefore, Dd can be assigned to the α-D atoms of the coordinated THF-d 8, and Fd to the β-D atoms. In the 1H NMR spectrum, the corresponding resonance F overlapped with the intense resonances of toluene and DFB. The integral intensity of the resonance D corresponds to ca. 8H, indicating that two THF molecules are incorporated into 2. The presence of “exceeded” amount of THF is not surprising: the crystals of the complex 1 contain clathrated THF molecules. Formation of 2 in the system 1/AlMe3/[Ph3C][B(C6F5)4] is accompanied by the appearance of the 1H resonance of 1,1,1-triphenylethane. The ratio of integral intensities of Me-resonances of 2 and Ph3CCH3 (4:1) corresponds to equal concentrations of 2 and Ph3CCH3. Thus, complex 2 is an ion pair formed upon Me-anion abstraction from the methylated vanadium complex of the type L3,5−MeVMexCl3-x (x=0−2). The 2H NMR spectrum of the sample 1/Al(CD3)3/[Ph3C][B(C6F5)4] displays a resonance of 1,1,1-triphenylethane-d 3 and no signals from terminal Al(CD3)2-group, expected for heterobinuclear ion pair of the type L3,5−MeV(R)(μ-R)2Al(CD3)2 (R=CD3 or Cl) [32]. This result in combination with the presence of two THF molecules in the structure of 2 (see above) indicates that heterobinuclear ion pairs (cf. Ref. [32]) are not formed in the system 1/AlMe3/[Ph3C][B(C6F5)4]. Most plausibly, 2 may be assigned to an ion pair with proposed structure [L3,5−MeVMe2(THF)2]+[B(C6F5)4]− (Scheme 2 ). We suggest the complete Cl substitution by Me-groups because increasing the Al/V ratio up to 50/1 don’t leads to any changes in the 1H NMR. Unfortunately, the V-Me resonances of 2 were not found both in 1H and 2H NMR spectra, apparently because the direct coordination of Me-group to the paramagnetic center led to very high paramagnetic shift and paramagnetic broadening. Complex 2 is stable at −40°C for several hours. The concentration of 2 in the sample 1/AlMe3/[Ph3C][B(C6F5)4] in toluene-d 8/DFB at −40 °C corresponds to ∼70±10% of total vanadium concentration. After warming the sample to −20 °C, 2 rapidly disappears, probably via reduction of vanadium to lower-valent states. 3.4 Reaction of 1 with MAO The 1H NMR spectrum of the sample 1/MAO ([Al]/[V]=40:1, [V]=0.01M) in toluene-d 8/DFB at −40 °C displays broad and low-intensive resonances of a new poorly soluble complex 3 (Fig. 4 ). The resonances A, B, and C of the α-diimine ligand of 3 were observed using 1H spectroscopy. 2H NMR spectrum of the sample 1a/MAO displayed only weak resonance Ad at δ 120 (Δn 1/2 ∼350Hz). The 2H NMR resonances Bd and Ed of the sample 1b/MAO were not detected due to the overlapping with the toluene and DFB resonances. All resonances observed had positions similar to those of the corresponding peaks in the spectrum of 2, but their widths were 2–3 times larger than in the case of complex 2 (Table 3). No resonances of coordinated THF and AlMe3 were detected. The possible structure of 3 will be discussed below. The addition of a 10-fold excess of THF to the sample 1/MAO leads to the formation of a new complex 4. The 1H and 2H NMR spectra of 2 and 4 (Fig. 5 , Table 3) are very similar that indicates that both complexes have similar structures, and thus 4 can be reasonably assigned to the ion pair [L3,5−MeVMe2(THF)2]+[MeMAO]− (Chart 2). Complex 3 displays 1H and 2H resonances of the α-diimine ligand; no coordinated THF and AlMe3 molecules were detected. The line widths of the corresponding resonances of 3 are 2–3 times broader than those of 4. We propose that 3 is a zwitter-ion like complex of the type [L3,5−MeVMe2 +⟵MeMAO−]. 3.5 Possible active species of ethylene polymerization According to our catalytic data, the system 1/MAO displayed moderate activity in ethylene polymerization (Table 1). The addition of THF substantially attenuated the catalytic activity (Table 1, entry 2), which resulted in the formation of only trace amounts of PE. The system 1/AlMe3/[CPh3][B(C6F5)4] was poorly active in ethylene polymerization (Table 1, entry 3). According to the NMR spectroscopic data, the systems 1/AlMe3/[Ph3C][B(C6F5)4] and 1/MAO/THF contain ion pairs 2 and 4, respectively. The 5th and 6th coordination sites of 2 and 4 are occupied by THF (strong Lewis base), which thus blocks ethylene coordination to vanadium. On the other hand, the system 1/MAO is polymerization-active, and the ion-pair 3 observed therein exhibits no coordinated THF molecules. We expect that 3 is the closest precursor of the active sites of ethylene polymerization by the catalyst system 1/MAO. 4 Conclusions In summary, the activation of α-diimine vanadium(III) pre-catalyst L3,5−MeVIIICl3(THF) {L3,5−Me =1,4-bis-3,5-dimethylpheny-2,3-dimethyl-1,4-diazabuta-1,3-diene} with AlMe3/[Ph3C][B(C6F5)]4 and MAO has been studied by 1H and 2H NMR spectroscopy. Ion pairs of the type [L3,5−MeVMe2(THF)2]+[B(C6F5)4]− and [L3.5−MeVMe2 +⟵MeMAO−] have been identified at −40°C as the prevailing species in the systems 1/AlMe3/[Ph3C][B(C6F5)]4 and 1/MAO, respectively. These ion pairs differ from the heterobinuclear ion pairs [L1(R)VIII(μ-R)2AlMe2]+[A]− (L1 =bis(imino)pyridine ligand, [A]− =[B(C6F5)4]− or [MeMAO]−, R=Me or Cl) formed upon the activation of bis(imino)pyridine vanadium(III) complexes with the same co-catalysts. Apparently, the structure of the α-diimine vanadium catalysts allows the formation of ‘tight ion-pairs’, or zwitterionic intermediates, whereas the less open gap aperture of the vanadium bis(imino)pyridine complexes restricts direct coordination of the MeMAO− counteranion, favoring instead the formation of the heterobinuclear adduct with AlMe3. Previously, a similar regularity was documented for titanocene catalysts: while sterically open half-titanocenes and constrained-geometry complexes afforded zwitterionic intermediates, titanocenes gave a mixture of heterobinuclear and zwitterionic species, and for the less open ansa-titanocenes, only heterobinuclear intermediates were documented [38–40]. Acknowledgements This work was supported by the Russian Foundation for Basic Research (grants No16-03-00236 and 16-53-53014). The authors thank Dr. D. E. Babushkin for fruitful discussions and for the synthesis of Al(CD3)3. Technical assistance from Mrs. O. K. Akmalova, Mrs. T.G. Ryzhkova, and Mrs. M.P. Vanina is gratefully acknowledged. coredata.dc:description: 1H and 2H NMR spectroscopic characterization of the V(III) ion-pair intermediates formed upon the activation of α-diimine vanadium(III) chloride L3,5−MeVIIICl3(THF) (L3,5−Me =1,4-bis-3,5-dimethylphenyl-2,3-dimethyl-1,4-diazabuta-1,3-diene) with AlMe3/[Ph3C][B(C6F5)]4 and MAO is reported. In contrast to previously reported heterobinuclear ion pairs of the type [L1(R)VIII(μ-R)2AlMe2]+[A]− (L1 =bis(imino)pyridine ligand, [A]− =[B(C6F5)4]− or [MeMAO]−, R=Me or Cl), species of the type [L3,5−MeVMe2(THF)2]+[B(C6F5)4]−, [L3,5−MeVMe2(THF)2]+[MeMAO]− and [L3,5−MeVMe2 +⟵MeMAO−] were identified.
coredata.dc:title: 1H and 2H NMR spectroscopic study of the ion pairs formed upon the activation of vanadium(III) α-diimine pre-catalyst with AlMe3/[Ph3C][B(C6F5)4] and MAO
coredata.prism:publicationName: Journal of Molecular Catalysis A: Chemical
